Dear Mr. Sabbagh:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The corrective action
plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result in
compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact me. The
corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an acceptable corrective action
plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any questions. In
the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone immediately, please contact
the area manager at (517) 243-9743.
Sincerely,
Heather A Reilly, Licensing Consultant

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code License recommendation
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12325
Section (1) An agency shall recommend to the department the appropriate
Description licensing action consistent with facts contained in the foster home
evaluation and any special evaluations.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation The agency completed a special evaluation which determined a
foster home was in compliance with licensing rules, although the
foster home allowed a youth to restrain another youth, violating
foster home licensing rule 400.9404.
Investigation On 2/14/24 Complainant reported the agency completed a special
evaluation for a foster home and did not cite a violation, although
one was documented. Complainant provided a copy of the special
evaluation report and noted the report verified Foster Parent and
Youth B (age 15) restrained Youth A (age 6) on her bed.
Complainant indicated per Public Act 116, restraint of a foster
child is not permitted. Therefore, the agency should have found
Foster Parent in violation of rule R 400.9404 (4).
On 2/14/24 Complainant was contacted via email for
additional information. Per Complainant, the special evaluation
report indicated Foster Parent was advised by Foster Care Worker
that restraint with Youth A was appropriate. Foster Care Worker
was employed with another agency, as this was a borrowed bed
situation.
On 2/15/24 Chief Administrator was contacted by phone, but
out of the office. A follow-up email was sent to Chief
Administrator and Program Manager to provide information about
2

the allegation and investigation process. Program Manager
responded with information to schedule interviews with staff.
On 3/6/24 Chief Administrator and Program Manager were
informed of the preliminary findings of the investigation.
On 2/16/24 a joint interview with Licensing Supervisor and
Licensing Worker 1 occurred via Teams. Both staff reported
Foster Parent accepted placement of Youth A in order to reunify
siblings in her home. Youth A is Youth B’s sister. Licensing
Supervisor reported this is a borrowed bed situation and Youth A’s
worker is with another agency. Regarding the special evaluation
both staff stated they did not feel the incident was a “restraint” as it
was not being used as discipline. Both staff indicated they did not
believe it was a licensing rule violation as it was physical
intervention to keep a child safe, as allowed by rules. Licensing
Worker 1 stated she was new to licensing and may have used the
word “restraint” when she meant something different. Licensing
Worker 1 reported she saw the video and described it as a hold,
using some pressure, in order to keep the child safe. Licensing
Worker 1 stated the restraint was initiated as Youth A had tried to
jump out a window and was banging her head, trying to harm
herself. Foster Parent was able to get Youth A to lay on her
mattress, while Youth B put his hands on Youth A’s arms to sooth
her. Foster Parent had her hands on Youth B’s legs, in a soothing
way. It did not appear they were holding Youth A down, as she
was able to move her body. Licensing Worker 1 reported Youth
A’s worker (Foster Care Worker) told Foster Parent it was ok to
have Youth B assist in the hold as Youth A felt comforted by him.
Licensing Worker 1 believed there was no violation as the hold
seemed reasonable to ensure safety and followed the plan set by
Foster Care Worker. Licensing Supervisor asked if having a
sibling assist to comfort a child was a violation. DCWL explained
that children cannot assist in restraining another child. Licensing
Supervisor asked for clarification about “restraint” as the rules
state a brief hold is acceptable intervention. Licensing Supervisor
asked to have some gray areas of the rule clarified as Foster
Parent was interested in maintaining placement but needed
information to stay in compliance when addressing Youth A’s self-
harming behavior. Agency was advised to use tools available such
as the Technical Assistance manual, definitions in Public Act 116,
or consulting with DCWL about any situations in which they were
unsure.
On 2/16/24 a follow-up email was sent to Licensing Supervisor
and Licensing Worker 1, asking for clarification about the
statement that Foster Parent “got her (Youth A) to” lay on the
3

mattress. Licensing Worker 1 responded that Foster Parent
grabbed Youth A by her hips and “shifted her down” to the
mattress.
On 2/20/24 Foster Care Worker was interviewed via phone.
Prior to the interview, Foster Care Worker (FCW) was contacted
via email on 2/26/24 and confirmed there was not a written safety
plan regarding physical intervention in Youth A’s case record.
During the interview, FCW stated she believed Foster Parent had
the type of license that allowed her to restrain youth. FCW was
informed by DCWL there is not a license type that allows restraint.
When asked if Youth A’s safety plan allowed for Foster Parent and
Youth B to restrain her, FCW stated that Youth B is good at
calming down Youth A. FCW saw the video of the restraint and felt
Youth B was not holding Youth A down hard. Youth A did not have
any marks or bruises. FCW asked Youth A about the restraint
later and she reported she was not hurt. When asked to clarify the
hold, FCW stated Youth A was forcefully trying to get up, but she
was unable to as Youth B was holding her arms and Foster Parent
was holding her legs. FCW stated there was not a written plan for
that type of restraint. However, FCW admitted she did verbally tell
Foster Parent that it was ok for Youth B to help hold Youth A
down. FCW stated she was aware Foster Parent tried,
unsuccessfully, to calm and soothe Youth A prior to the restraint.
However, Youth A continued to escalate, and Foster Parent was
concerned for her physical safety. FCW reported she was
completing this interview while at the hospital with Youth A. Youth
A was completing a screening due to her self-harming behaviors.
FCW was unsure if Youth A would be admitted or return to Foster
Parent’s home. It was discussed that restraint was not permitted
and that a written safety plan was needed if Youth A returned to
the foster home.
On 2/26/24 FCW was provided with resources about DHHS
Clinical Review, as Youth A may be a candidate for that service.
On 2/22/24 Licensing Supervisor and Licensing Worker 2
requested consultation from DCWL via Teams. Licensing
Supervisor reported Youth A was returning to the foster home that
evening. Licensing Supervisor and Licensing Worker 2 asked how
Foster Parent could physically intervene with Youth A’s dangerous
behaviors in a way that would keep the child safe, and not violate
licensing rules. The agency requested clarification on the
difference between physical restraint versus acceptable physical
intervention. Different scenarios were discussed regarding
behaviors Youth A had exhibited such as banging her head, trying
4

to jump out a window, running into traffic, and putting things in her
mouth. Clarification was provided that holding, hugging, moving a
child as a life-saving measure to prevent harm to self or others
would be physical intervention. Restricting movement of a child
that is not presenting “imminent” harm would be considered
restraint. If a child were in a situation where there was immediate
risk of harm, the foster parent could physically intervene as a
safety measure but must not restrict the child when the risk is
lowered.
On 3/4/24 Foster Parent was contacted via email to schedule
an interview. Foster Parent responded she was in the midst of a
medical emergency for a youth and requested questions to be
sent via email for her response. Foster Parent responded on
3/5/24 and reported she accepted placement of Youth A In
October 2023, aware of her suicidal/homicidal ideations and
threats. At the time of placement, the case moved from one
agency to another. Foster Parent was unaware of any prior safety
or behavior plans.
Foster Parent reported that Youth B stepped in at times to assist
his sister. Foster Parent reflected that she had observed Youth B
holding Youth A like a baby at their prior placement, which helped
Youth A calm down. Foster Parent observed that at times Youth B
is very effective at providing a safe place and calming Youth A.
During the incident that was investigated by the agency, Youth B
and Foster Parent held Youth A’s arms and legs loosely, allowing
her to move, but restricting her when she would attempt to bite,
bang her head on the headboard, kick the wall, or try to scratch
them. Foster Parent stated Youth A’s Occupational Therapist said
that restricted movement was a good thing for her because it
created a deeper sensory input for her and helped her tire out or
calm down faster. Foster Parent stated she became aware that
Youth B could not assist with holds when the agency informed her
recently. Foster Parent has attempted to hold Youth A on her own
but has been unable as Youth A is strong when she is determined
to harm herself. Recently, when Youth A was in the hospital for 6
days, it took three staff to hold her and prevent her from harming
herself.
Since the special evaluation, agency staff have provided
clarification regarding physical intervention and restraint.
Licensing Worker 2 discussed several scenarios with Foster
Parent and potential appropriate physical interventions if needed.
Foster Care Worker developed a formal safety plan/behavior plan
5

with Foster Parent, including recommendations from the Child
Psychiatrist.
Documents reviewed:
• Special evaluation report identified incidents of Foster Child
1 attempting to harm herself. Foster Parent and Foster
Child 2 held Foster Child 1’s wrists and upper thighs while
she laid on the bed. Foster Parent took a video as advised
by Foster Care Worker. No marks or bruises were
observed. Foster Parent was found in compliance with
licensing rules. Agency reported the restraint followed the
licensing rule 9404 (2) as “reasonable method of physical
intervention”. The agency did not have a copy of the video.
• Review of Foster Home Licensing rule R 400.9404
Behavior management.
o (2) A foster parent may use reasonable restraint
methods of physical intervention to prevent a foster
child from harming himself or herself, or other
persons.
o (4) All the following are prohibited: (a) Corporal
punishment, any type of restraint, or any kind of
punishment inflicted on the body.
• Review of Public Act: Page 8- 722.112b Definitions. (h)
“personal restraint” means the application of physical force
without the use of a device, for the purpose of restraining
the free movement of a minor child's body. Personal
restraint does not include: (ii) Briefly holding a minor child
without undue force in order to calm or comfort him or her.
• Youth A’s MiSACWIS case record was reviewed. No
documentation was found to indicate restraint was part of a
safety plan or behavior management plan for Youth A prior
to the special evaluation.
• Safety plan dated 2/22/24 was signed by Foster Care
Worker. The plan outlined Youth A’s medication, parenting
time change, resources available to foster parent, and the
consultation from DCWL regarding appropriate physical
intervention.
Analysis The agency is found in noncompliance as it was determined the
agency did not cite a violation for an incident where the foster
parent and another child in the home, physically restrained a
foster child by holding them down and restricting their arms and
legs.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE:
6

The agency was provided with guidance regarding the difference
between physical intervention to keep a child safe from injury,
versus physical restraint. The agency was advised to contact
DCWL to discuss any situations they were unsure of. The agency
was informed that children cannot assist in physical restraint or
any behavior management of another child. The agency was
provided with the Public Act-116 definition of restraint. The agency
was also provided information about the clinical review process
available for youth with mental health needs and behavioral
concerns.
Conclusion Violation Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
